panels.title: web Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.content:
### Description

The imagescaler rescales images before sending them to clients. This allows faster transmission of
images and faster rendering of web pages.

Aggregation of most web requests that pass through the puma to the GitLab rails monolith.
Healthchecks are excluded.

panels.content:
### Description

The number of requests meeting their duration target based on the urgency
of the endpoint. By default, a request should take no more than 1s. But
this can be adjusted by endpoint.

Read more about this in the [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/application_slis/rails_request_apdex.html).



### Observability Tools

panels.title: Details

panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

seriesOverrides.alias: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: workhorse SLI Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_5m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_30m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_6h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: Error rates are a measure of unhandled service exceptions per second. Client errors are excluded when possible. Lower is better

seriesOverrides.alias: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: workhorse SLI Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_5m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_30m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_6h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="web"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="web"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.
panels.title: workhorse SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

Aggregation of most web requests that pass through workhorse, monitored via the HTTP interface.
Excludes health, readiness and liveness requests. Some known slow requests, such as HTTP uploads,
are excluded from the apdex score.



### Observability Tools

* [Google Stackdriver Continuous Profiling](https://console.cloud.google.com/profiler;timespan=4h/workhorse-web;type=CPU/cpu?project=gitlab-production)
* [üêû Sentry Releases: gitlab/gitlab-workhorse-gitlabcom](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlab-workhorse-gitlabcom/releases?environment=${environment})

panels.description: Network utilization
panels.title: web Deployment: Network IO

panels.description:
Ratio of requested CPU resources from allocatable resources.
Ideally we have requests utilization close to 100%. Values are
below 100% typically because pods do not fit well on nodes or
because we might be bound by memory requests already.
panels.title: Node CPU Requests Utilization

panels.description:
Ratio of requested Memory resources from allocatable resources.
Ideally we have requests utilization close to 100%. Values are
below 100% typically because pods do not fit well on nodes or
because we might be bound by CPU requests already.
panels.title: Node Memory Requests Utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. When this is exhausted, the container may be thottled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Records the total memory utilization for containers for this service, as a percentage of
the memory limit as configured through Kubernetes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
Measures Go memory usage as a percentage of container memory limit
 Lower is better.
panels.title: kube_go_memory component saturation: Go Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
The [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/)
automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler has a configured upper maximum. When this
limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and other
resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, horizontalpodautoscaler, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|imports|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other"}
      /
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|imports|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_desired_replicas component saturation: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Desired Replicas

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in the node pool for
a service fleet.

If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs horizontal scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total:labeled{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_pool_cpu component saturation: Average Node Pool CPU Utilization

panels.description:
A GKE kubernetes node pool is close to it's maximum number of nodes.

The maximum is defined in terraform, via the `max_node_count` field of a node pool. The limit is per-zone, so for
single zone clusters the number of nodes will match the limit, for regional clusters, the limit is multiplied by
the number of zones the cluster is deployed over.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, cluster, label_pool, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      count by (cluster, env, environment, label_pool, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        kube_node_labels:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
      )
      / on(cluster, env, environment, label_pool) group_left() (
        label_replace(
          terraform_report_google_cluster_node_pool_max_node_count,
          "label_pool", "$0", "pool_name", ".*"
        )
        * on(cluster, env, environment) group_left()
        count by (cluster, env, environment) (
          group by (cluster, env, environment, label_topology_kubernetes_io_zone) (
            kube_node_labels:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
          )
        )
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_pool_max_nodes component saturation: Kube Pool Max Node Limit

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.
panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance

panels.description:
Rails uses connection pools for its database connections. As each
node may have multiple connection pools, this is by node and by
database host.

Read more about this resource in our [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/client_side_connection_pool.html#client-side-connection-pool).

If this resource is saturated, it may indicate that our connection
pools are not correctly sized, perhaps because an unexpected
application thread is using a database connection.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, instance, host, port) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        avg_over_time(gitlab_database_connection_pool_busy{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[5m])
        +
        avg_over_time(gitlab_database_connection_pool_dead{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[5m])
      )
      /
      gitlab_database_connection_pool_size{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: rails_db_connection_pool component saturation: Rails DB Connection Pool Utilization

panels.description:
Ruby (technically Ruby MRI), like some other scripting languages, uses a Global VM lock (GVL) also known as a
Global Interpreter Lock (GIL) to ensure that multiple threads can execute safely. Ruby code is only allowed to
execute in one thread in a process at a time. When calling out to c extensions, the thread can cede the lock to
other thread while it continues to execute.

This means that when CPU-bound workloads run in a multithreaded environment such as Puma or Sidekiq, contention
with other Ruby worker threads running in the same process can occur, effectively slowing thoses threads down as
they await GVL entry.

Often the best fix for this situation is to add more workers by scaling up the fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn, pod) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      rate(ruby_process_cpu_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[10m])
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: ruby_thread_contention component saturation: Ruby Thread Contention

panels.description:
Puma thread utilization per node.

Puma uses a fixed size thread pool to handle HTTP requests. This metric shows how many threads are busy handling requests. When this resource is saturated,
we will see puma queuing taking place. Leading to slowdowns across the application.

Puma saturation is usually caused by latency problems in downstream services: usually Gitaly or Postgres, but possibly also Redis.
Puma saturation can also be caused by traffic spikes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (avg_over_time(instance:puma_active_connections:sum{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[1m]))
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (instance:puma_max_threads:sum{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"})
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: single_node_puma_workers component saturation: Puma Worker Saturation per Node

panels.description:
Workhorse can scale images on-the-fly as requested. Since the actual work will be
performed by dedicated processes, we currently define a hard cap for how many
such requests are allowed to be in the system concurrently.

If this resource is fully saturated, Workhorse will start ignoring image scaling
requests and serve the original image instead, which will ensure continued operation,
but comes at the cost of additional client latency and GCS egress traffic.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg_over_time(gitlab_workhorse_image_resize_processes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}[5m])
        /
      gitlab_workhorse_image_resize_max_processes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="web"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: workhorse_image_scaling component saturation: Workhorse Image Scaler Exhaustion per Node
